title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Infinite limits
We say that \(f(x)\) has an infinite limit for \(x \to a\) if the values of \(f(x)\) become arbitrarily large when \(x \to a\).
We note
\[
  \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = \infty \quad \text{or} \quad \lim_{x \to a}f(x) = -\infty,
\]
depending on the sign of \(f(x)\) near \(x = a\).
Examples:

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0}\frac{1}{x^2}\)
\(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0+} \ln x\)

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Vertical asymptotes
The line \(x = a\) is a vertical asymptote of \(f(x)\) if at least one of the following is true:
\[
  \lim_{x \to a+} f(x) = \pm\infty \quad \text{or} \quad \lim_{x \to a-}f(x) = \pm\infty.
\]
Example: find the vertical asymptotes of

\(\displaystyle y = \ln x\)
\(\displaystyle y = \tan x\)

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Example
Find all vertical asymptotes of the function
\[
  f(x) = \frac{|x-1|}{x^2-3x+2}.
\]
Hint: Look for zeros of the denominator that are not zeros of the numerator.

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Limits at infinity (intuition)
What happens to \(f(x)\) when \(x\) becomes very large (positive/negative)?
Examples:

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \pm \infty} \frac{x^2 - 1}{x^2 + 1}\)
\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to +\infty}e^{-x}\)

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Limits at infinity (definition)
We write:


\[
    \lim_{x \to +\infty} f(x) = L
\]



\[
     \lim_{x \to -\infty}f(x) = M
\]


We mean:



\(f(x)\) is defined on an interval \((a, +\infty)\)
\(f(x)\) gets as close as we want to \(L\) by taking \(x\) large enough.





\(f(x)\) is defined on an interval \((-\infty, b)\)
\(f(x)\) gets as close as we want to \(M\) by taking \(x\) large enough (in the negative direction).

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Horizontal asymptotes
The line \(y = L\) is a horizontal asymptote of \(f(x)\) if at least one of the following is true:
\[
    \lim_{x \to +\infty}f(x) = L \quad \text{or} \lim_{x \to -\infty}f(x) = L.
\]
Examples: Find the horizontal asymptotes of

\(\displaystyle y = \frac{x^2 - 1}{x^2 + 1}\)
\(\displaystyle y = e^{-x}\)
\(\displaystyle y = \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}}\)

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Limit laws

\(\lim_{x \to \infty} x = \infty\)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} c = c\) (for \(c\) a constant)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty}(f(x) + g(x)) = \lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) + \lim_{x \to \infty} g(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} (cf(x)) = c\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty}(f(x)g(x)) = \lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) \lim_{x \to \infty} g(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \frac{\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x)}{\lim_{x \to \infty} g(x)}\), if the denominator is not zero

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Limit laws (continued)

\(\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x)^{m/n} = \left(\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) \right)^{m/n} = L^{m/n}\), if

\(L \ge 0\) for \(n\) even
\(L \ne 0\) for \(m\) negative

If \(f(x) \le g(x)\), then \(\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) \le \lim_{x \to \infty} g(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} 1/x^n = 0\), if \(n > 0\)
\(\lim_{x \to \infty} g(f(x)) = \lim_{y \to c} g(y)\), where \(c = \lim_{x\to \infty}f(x)\), if

\(c\) is constant (not equal to \(\pm \infty\))
\(f\) is continuous (see later)

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Continuity

Intuitively, continuity \(=\) “no jumps”
Mathematically, \(f(x)\) is continuous at an interior point \(x = a\) of its domain if

\[
  \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = f(a).
\]
Example: \(\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^2 - x - 3}{x - 2}\) is not continuous at \(x = 2\).

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Examples
Define \(f(x) = \frac{x^2 - x - 2}{x - 2}\) when \(x \ne 2\) and \(f(x) = 1\) otherwise (i.e. \(f(2) = 1\)). Is \(f(x)\) continuous at \(x = 2\)?

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Left/right continuity
At \(x = a\), \(f(x)\) is …

Right continuous if \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a+} f(x) = f(a)\)
Left continuous if \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a-} f(x) = f(a)\).

Example: the Heaviside function is defined by \(H(x) = 0\) when \(x < 0\) and \(H(x) = 1\) when \(x \ge 0\). Is \(H(x)\) right or left continuous at \(x = 0\)?

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Continuity on an interval
The function \(f(x)\) is continuous on an interval \([a, b]\) if …

\(f(x)\) is continuous at every \(x \in (a, b)\)
\(f(x)\) is right-continuous in \(a\)
\(f(x)\) is left-continuous in \(b\).

Example: Show that \(f(x) = 1 - \sqrt{1 - x^2}\) is continuous on \([-1, 1]\).

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
section: Making new continuous functions out of old ones
text:
Making new continuous functions out of old ones
If \(f(x), g(x)\) are continuous at \(x = a\), and \(c\) is a constant, then the following are also continuous at \(x = a\):

\(f + g\)
\(f - g\)
\(cf\)
\(fg\)
\(f/g\) (if \(g(a) \ne 0\))

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Which functions are continuous?
Continuous on their domain:

Polynomials
Rational functions
Trigonometric functions + inverse trigonometric functions
Square roots, \(n\)th roots
\(\log\), \(\exp\)

In particular:

Polynomials are continuous for all \(x \in \mathbb{R}\)
Rational functions \(P(x)/Q(x)\) are continuous for all \(x\) so that \(Q(x) \ne 0\).

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Composition of functions
If \(f(x)\) is continuous and \(\lim_{x \to a} g(x) = b\), then
\[
    \lim_{x \to a} f(g(x)) = f(b) = f\left( \lim_{x \to b} g(x) \right).
\]
Example: \(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 2} \sin\left( \frac{2-x}{4-x^2}\pi\right)\)

title: Limits and Continuity (2/2)
text:
Corollary
If \(g\) is continuous at \(x = a\) and \(f\) is continuous at \(y = g(a)\), then \(f \circ g\) is continuous at \(x = a\).
Examples: Where are the following functions continuous?

\(\displaystyle h(x) = \sin x^2\)
\(\displaystyle h(x) = \ln(1 + \cos x)\)

title: Derivatives (2/2): Applications
text:
Implicit differentiation

We now know how to compute the derivative of a function \(y = f(x)\).
But what if we can’t write \(y\) as a function of \(x\)?

Example: Find \(y'(x)\) if \(x\) and \(y\) are related by \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\).
Two ways of solving:

The direct way (hard): find \(y(x)\) and differentiate
Via implicit differentiation (easy): differentiate both sides

title: Derivatives (2/2): Applications
text:
Velocity and acceleration
We will consider only objects moving along a straight line (one-dimensional motion)

Position \(x(t)\)
Velocity \(v(t)\)

Recall from physics 1: \(v(t)\) is the first derivative of \(x(t)\). Why?

title: Derivatives (2/2): Applications
text:
Average and instantaneous velocity, speed

The average velocity \(v_\text{avg}(t)\) over an interval \([t, t+h]\) is the change in distance divided by the change in time:

\[
    v_{\text{avg}}(t) = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x(t+h) - x(t)}{h}.
\]

The instantaneous velocity \(v(t)\) is the limit as \(h \to 0\):

\[
    v(t) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{x(t+h) - x(t)}{h} = \frac{dx}{dt} = \dot{x}(t).
\]

The speed \(s(t)\) is the magnitude of the velocity: \(s(t) = |v(t)|\).

title: Derivatives (2/2): Applications
text:
Characteristics of velocity

\(v(t) > 0\): moving to the right (\(x(t)\) increases)
\(v(t) < 0\): moving to the left (\(x(t)\) decreases)
\(v(t) = 0\): instantaneously at rest

title: Derivatives (2/2): Applications
text:
Acceleration
The acceleration \(a(t)\) is the rate of change of the velocity:
\[
    a(t) = \dot{v}(t) = \ddot{x}(t).
\]
Characteristics:

\(a(t) > 0\): \(v(t)\) increases
\(a(t) < 0\): \(v(t)\) decreases

Speeding up and slowing down:

\(a(t) \cdot v(t) > 0\): speeding up
\(a(t) \cdot v(t) < 0\): slowing down

title: Derivatives (2/2): Applications
text:

A particle \(P\) moves along the \(x\)-axis with position given by \(x(t) = 2 t^3 - 15 t^2 + 24t\).

Find \(v(t)\) and \(a(t)\).
In which direction is \(P\) moving at \(t = 2\)? Is \(P\) speeding up or slowing down?
When is \(P\) instantaneously at rest? When does its velocity instantaneously not change?

title: Coordinate Geometry

What is coordinate geometry?
Studying geometry through coordinate calculations.

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Example: distance between two points


Distance between \(P\) and \(Q\):
\[
    d(P, Q) = \sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}
\]

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Example: midpoint between two points


Coordinates of midpoint between \(P\) and \(Q\):
\[
  M = \left( \frac{x_1 + x_2}{2}, \frac{y_1 + y_2}{2} \right).
\]

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Locus of points
“Locus” = Set of points satisfying some condition.

Circle: All points at given distance from a fixed center.
Ellipse: All points for which the sum of distances to two fixed points (focal points) is constant
Parabola: All points that are at equal distance from a fixed point and a given line (directrix)

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Example
Find the locus of points for which the distance to the \(x\)-axis is equal to the distance to the point \((0, 1)\).

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Circles
Locus of points \(P(x, y)\) at distance \(R\) from center \(C(h, k)\).


We have \(d(P, C) = R\) so that
\[
  \sqrt{(x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2} = R,
\]
and by squaring
\[
  \boxed{(x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = R^2}
\]

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Lines


Line not parallel to the \(y\)-axis:
\[
  \boxed{y = mx + q}
\]
with

\(m\): the slope
\(q\): the intercept

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Lines


Line parallel to the \(y\)-axis:
\[
  \boxed{x = a}
\]
with

\(a\): where the line intersects the \(x\)-axis

title: Coordinate Geometry
section: Finding the slope of a line
text:
Finding the slope of a line


Take

\(\Delta x = x_2 - x_1\)
\(\Delta y = y_2 - y_1\)

Then
\[
  \boxed{m = \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}}
\]
“\(\Delta x\) steps to the right, \(\Delta y\) steps up/down.”

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Example
Find the equation for the line through \((1, 5)\) and \((2, 7)\).

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Properties
Equation for the line through \((x_0, y_0)\) with slope \(m\):
\[
  y - y_0 = m(x - x_0)
\]
Equation for the line through the points \((x_1, y_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2)\):
\[
  y - y_1 = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}(x - x_1).
\]

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Parallel/perpendicular lines

Two lines are parallel if their slopes are the same: \(\boxed{m_1 = m_2}\)
Two lines are perpendicular if their slopes satisfy: \(\boxed{m_1 m_2 = -1}\)

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Example
Given two lines \(L_1: x + 2y - 3 = 0\) and \(L_2: kx + y - 5 = 0\), for which value of \(k\) are \(L_1\) and \(L_2\) …

Parallel?
Perpendicular?

title: Coordinate Geometry
section: Distance of a point to a line
text:
Distance of a point to a line


Distance between point \(P(x_0, y_0)\) and line \(L: ax + by + c = 0\):
\[
  D = \frac{|ax_0 + by_0 + c|}{\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}}.
\]

title: Coordinate Geometry
text:
Different representations of lines

Slope/intercept:

\(y = mx + q\) (not parallel to \(y\)-axis)
\(x = a\) (parallel)

Linear representation: \(ax + by + c = 0\)
Polar representation:

\[
   r = \frac{q}{\sin \theta - m \cos \theta}
\]

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Motivation: tangent lines
In the previous class, we managed to compute the slope of the tangent line to the parabola \(y = x^2\) by computing the limit
\[
    m = \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x^2 - 1}{x - 1} = 2.
\]
How would we do this for an arbitrary curve \(y = f(x)\)?

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Derivative of a function
We define the derivative of \(f(x)\) at \(x = a\) (“f prime”) as
\[
    f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x - a} \quad \text{(if the limit exists)}.
\]
If we put \(h = x - a\), we can rewrite this as
\[
    f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(a + h) - f(a)}{h}.
\]
This is sometimes easier to compute.
If \(f'(a)\) exists, we say that \(f(x)\) is differentiable at \(x = a\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Examples
Compute the derivative of \(f(x) = 3x^2 + 7x - 5\) at \(x = 1\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Examples
Compute the derivative of \(f(x) = |x|\) at \(x = a\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
The derivative as a function
By letting \(a\) vary in \(f'(a)\), we obtain a function given by
\[
    f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \quad \text{(if the limit exists)}.
\]
There are many notations for the derivative function: for \(y = f(x)\),
\[
    f'(x) = y' = \frac{d f}{d x} = \frac{d y}{d x} = \frac{d}{dx} f(x).
\]
all mean the same thing.

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Example
Show that \(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} \sqrt{x} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Properties of differentiable functions
We say that \(y = f(x)\) is differentiable on an interval \([a, b]\) if

\(f'(x)\) exists for each \(x \in (a, b)\)
At \(x = a\), the right derivative exists: \[f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0+}\frac{f(a + h) - f(a)}{h}.\]
At \(x = b\), the left derivative exists: \[f'(b) = \lim_{h \to 0-}\frac{f(b + h) - f(b)}{h}.\]

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Link between differentiability and continuity

If \(f(x)\) is differentiable at \(x = a\), then \(f(x)\) is also continuous at \(x = a\).
The converse is not necessarily true!

Example: Show that \(y = |x|\) is differentiable for all \(x \ne 0\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Higher-order derivatives
Now that we can take the derivative of a function, we can take the derivative of the derivative, and so on…



Notation
Name




\(f'(x)\)
1st-order derivative


\(f''(x) = \frac{d}{dx} f'(x)\)
2nd-order derivative


…
…


\(f^{(n)}(x) = \frac{d}{dx} f^{(n-1)}(x)\)
\(n\)th-order derivative

title: Derivatives (1/2)
section: Derivative of a polynomial: basic rules
text:
Derivative of a polynomial: basic rules

\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} c = 0\)
\(\displaystyle \frac{d x^n}{dx} = nx^{n-1}\) for \(n \ne 0\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
section: Derivative of a polynomial: basic rules
text:
Derivative of a polynomial: basic rules

\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}(cf(x)) = c\frac{d f}{dx}\).
\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}(f(x) + g(x)) = \frac{d f}{dx} + \frac{dg}{dx}\).

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Examples

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Derivative of the exponential/logarithm
\[\begin{align*}
    \frac{d}{dx} e^x & = e^x \\
    \frac{d}{dx} \ln x & = \frac{1}{x}.
\end{align*}\]
For a different base: \[\begin{align*}
    \frac{d}{dx} a^x & = a^x \ln a \\
    \frac{d}{dx} \log_a x & = \frac{1}{x \ln a}
\end{align*}\]

The last two rules will follow from the chain rule
Do not confuse the rules for \(a^x\) and \(x^n\)!

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Product and quotient rules

\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}(f(x)g(x)) = f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x)\).
\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \frac{f'(x) g(x) - f(x) g'(x)}{g(x)^2}\).

Examples: Compute

\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}(x^2 e^x)\)
\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} \frac{x + 1}{x + 3}\)

title: Derivatives (1/2)
Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Examples
Using the rules from the previous slide, show that
\[\begin{align*}
    \frac{d}{dx} \csc x & = - \cot x \csc x \\
    \frac{d}{dx} \sec x & = \tan x \sec x \\
    \frac{d}{dx} \cot x & = - \csc^2 x
\end{align*}\]
Example solution:
\[
    \frac{d}{dx} \csc x = \frac{d}{dx} \frac{1}{\sin x} = \frac{1'\cdot \sin x - \sin'(x) \cdot 1}{\sin^2 x} = - \frac{\cos x}{\sin^2 x}.
\]
(This will be easier once we cover the chain rule)

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
\[\begin{align*}
    \frac{d}{dx} \arcsin x & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\
    \frac{d}{dx} \arccos x & = \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\    
    \frac{d}{dx} \arctan x & = \frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\
\end{align*}\]
These rules can be derived by means of implicit differentation, which we will cover later.

title: Derivatives (1/2)
text:
The chain rule

Useful for composite functions \(F = \color{red}{f} \circ \color{blue}{g}\) (“\(\color{red}{f}\) after \(\color{blue}{g}\)”)
If \(\color{red}{f}(x)\) and \(\color{blue}{g}(x)\) are differentiable, then the composite function \(F(x)\) is also differentiable and

\[
    F'(x) = \color{red}{f'}(\color{blue}{g}(x)) \cdot \color{blue}{g'}(x).
\]

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
Definition of limit


We write:

\[
    \lim_{x \to a}f(x) = L
\]

We say: “The limit of \(f(x)\) as \(x\) goes to \(a\) is \(L\)”.
We mean:

\(f(x)\) is defined for all \(x\) near \(a\) (possibly not \(a\) itself)
As \(x\) gets closer to \(a\), \(f(x)\) gets closer and closer to \(L\)

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
One-sided limits
Sometimes the limit exists on “one side” of the function.


\[
  \lim_{x\to \pi/2} \tan x = ?
\]

\(+\infty\) when \(x \to 0\) from right
\(-\infty\) when \(x \to 0\) from left

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
Definition


Left Limit:
\[
    \lim_{x \to a-}f(x) = L
\]

\(f(x)\) defined to the left of \(a\)
\(f(x) \to L\) as \(x \to a\) from the left









Right Limit:
\[
    \lim_{x \to a+}f(x) = M
\]

\(f(x)\) defined to the right of \(a\)
\(f(x) \to M\) as \(x \to a\) from the right

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
Relation with two-sided limit
The two-sided limit exists,
\[
    \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L,
\]
if and only if both one-sided limits exist and are equal:
\[
    \lim_{x \to a+} f(x) = L \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{x \to a-} f(x) = L
\]

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
Examples

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0+} \sqrt{x}\)
\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{|x|}{x}\)
\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 2} \frac{|x-2|}{x^2 + x - 6}\)
\(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to\pi}f(x)\), where \(f(x) = \sin x\) when \(x < \pi\) and \(f(x) = \sqrt{x - \pi}\) otherwise.

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
Limit laws

\(\lim_{x \to a} x = a\)
\(\lim_{x \to a} c = c\)
\(\lim_{x \to a} (f(x) + g(x)) = \lim_{x \to a} f(x) + \lim_{x \to a} g(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to a} (c(f(x))) = c \lim_{x \to a} f(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to a}(f(x)g(x)) = \lim_{x \to a}f(x) \lim_{x \to a}g(x)\)
\(\lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \frac{\lim_{x \to a}f(x)}{\lim_{x \to a}g(x)}\) if \(\lim_{x \to a} g(x) \ne 0\)
\(\lim_{x \to a}\left(f(x)^{m/n}\right) = \left( \lim_{x \to a}f(x) \right)^{m/n} = L^{m/n}\),

If \(n\) even: \(L\) must be positive
If \(m < 0\): \(L\) must be different from 0.

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
Limit laws

If \(f(x) = g(x)\) for all \(x \ne a\) close to \(a\), then \(\lim_{x \to a} f(x) = \lim_{x \to a}g(x)\).
If \(f(x) \le g(x)\) for all \(x \ne a\) close to \(a\), then \(\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \le \lim_{x \to a}g(x)\).

These laws also hold for one-sided limits, with appropriate modifications.

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
section: Limits of polynomials and rational functions
text:
Limits of polynomials and rational functions

Polynomial: \(P(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n\) \[
    \lim_{x \to a} P(x) = P(a).
\]
Rational function: \(F(x) = \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\), with \(P(x)\), \(Q(x)\) polynomials \[
    \lim_{x \to a} F(x) = \frac{\lim_{x \to a} P(x)}{\lim_{x \to a} Q(x)} = \frac{P(a)}{Q(a)}
    \quad \text{if $Q(a) \ne 0$}.
\]

title: Limits and Continuity (1/2)
text:
The squeeze theorem
Lets you compute the limit of a difficult function \(g(x)\) “squeezed” between two simple functions \(f(x)\) and \(h(x)\).
Suppose

\(f(x) \le g(x) \le h(x)\) for some \(x\) near \(a\)
\(\lim_{x \to a}f(x) = \lim_{x \to a} h(x) = L\).

Then
\[
\lim_{x \to a} h(x) = L.
\]
